results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.

results.title: 'Pardon me for being born into a nation of racists' T-shirt
results.brief_description: “The slogan on the T-shirt was from a poster I had made during the 1971 South African Springbok rugby tour of Australia, which drew massive anti-apartheid demonstarations in Australia.” - Gary Foley

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-06. First Nations

results.title: Rotted Luck
results.brief_description:
Rotted Luck envisions a slot machine overtaken by a living fungal network, playfully critiquing the addictive potential of gaming and gambling. The spinning reel displays familiar slot machine icons like cherries and lemons, but this game unfolds differently. The fruit spins uncontrollably and starts to decay as mould spreads across the screen. As you play, your movements are tracked through a cloud of spores that ultimately engulfs you.

Rotted Luck disrupts the usual interactivity and visual style of slot machines to encourage a stranger, shared and more joyful experience. By subverting conventional game mechanics, it proposes an outcome that isn’t about ‘winning’. Communal, non-addictive and movement-based, Rotted Luck favours the fun of play.

To create the piece, artists Vidya Rajan and Ian MacLarty studied slot machine design and imagined a fungus mistaking one for food. They photographed real decaying fruit, transformed them into 3D models, and used a common webcam to track player movements.

results.title: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.
results.brief_description: In 1951, this projector was brought to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia to entertain workers during the shearing season.

constellations_primary.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_primary.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

results.title_for_label: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.description: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. Situated on pastoral land in the Murray and Mellee region of South Australia, Koomooloo Station operated as a sheep station from 1868 and in 1951, this projector was bought to entertain workers during the shearing season. Luckily it has a vent at the back of the casing to keep it cool because if it was used inside a shearing shed the heat would’ve been insufferable.
